title: Closure outlives error should mention the source of the requirement

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

body:
The following code:

```rust
struct Inner;
struct Outer {
    field: Inner
}
fn use_it<R, F: FnOnce(&Outer) -> R>(_val: F) {}
fn main() {
    use_it(|outer| &outer.field)
}
```

produces the following error message as of `nightly-2020-06-07`

```
error: lifetime may not live long enough
 --> src/main.rs:7:20
  |
7 |     use_it(|outer| &outer.field)
  |             ------ ^^^^^^^^^^^^ returning this value requires that `'1` must outlive `'2`
  |             |    |
  |             |    return type of closure is &'2 Inner
  |             has type `&'1 Outer`
```

In general, returning a reference derived from an argument is perfectly fine. The issue is that `use_it` requires that the return type outlive the argument - however, this is not mentioned anywhere in the error message.

When we emit a lifetime error message for closures, we should try to find the reason for the requirement, and give a more detailed explanation to the user.
